content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provides for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Agreement, Animas-La Plata Project, Dolores Project, and Tribe/Tribes. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE COLORADO UTE INDIAN WATER RIGHTS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1988. After the enactment of the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, the Secretary is required to construct a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This project also includes a pumping plant, reservoir inlet conduit, and allocations of municipal and industrial water. The Animas-La Plata Project includes a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet, a pumping plant, and a reservoir inlet conduit. Municipal and industrial water allocations are made to the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, and Navajo Nation, with specific annual depletion limits for each tribe. The Animas-La Plata Project allocates water to various tribes and organizations, with specific annual depletion limits for each. This includes allocations to the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District. The Animas-La Plata Project allocates water to tribes and organizations, with specific annual depletion limits. Tribal construction costs are nonreimbursable, and nontribal water capital obligations are to be satisfied by specific entities. The Animas-La Plata Project requires specific entities to pay designated amounts to fulfill cost-sharing obligations. Nonreimbursable costs for certain project components include those related to recreation, environmental compliance, and mitigation. The State of Colorado entered into a cost-sharing agreement for the Animas-La Plata Project in 1986. Nonreimbursable costs for project components include those for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resource protection, and fish and wildlife enhancement. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use from the project require the Secretary to cover operation, maintenance, and replacement costs until the water is utilized by the Tribe. The Secretary will pay for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations until the water is used by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to reimburse these costs. Repayment of the pro rata share is required when the water allocation is first used by the Tribe. Repayment of pro rata share for water allocation by Tribe and bearing annual costs for Dolores Project. Amendments to Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act regarding remaining water supplies. Amendments to the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 regarding water allocations for the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District and La Plata Conservancy District. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary will provide additional water depletions if consistent with the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Secretary will allocate water depletions among the beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in accordance with an agreement. The Secretary shall transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries upon request of the State Engineer, in compliance with applicable State law. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in compliance with State law. The Final Supplement and Biological Opinion from 1996 will fulfill project requirements. The Final Biological Opinion from 1996, issued by the Department of the Interior, is considered adequate to meet requirements under the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 and construction of project facilities. The Final Biological Opinion from 1996 meets requirements under various acts for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, including construction of project facilities and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water approved in the biological opinion. This subsection does not affect the construction of facilities not described here or any water use not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Final Settlement: Providing water to the Tribes as per this section settles their water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. This does not impact their rights on other streams and rivers mentioned in the Agreement. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7, of the State of Colorado to request amendments to the final consent decree for the Colorado Ute Settlement Act. This ensures the Tribes' water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers are settled, while preserving their rights on other streams and rivers mentioned in the Agreement. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7, of the State of Colorado to request amendments to the final consent decree for the Colorado Ute Settlement Act, as per the amendments made under the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of that Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as described in specific appropriations acts. The Department of the Interior Appropriations Acts from 1992 to 1995, and the treatment of the uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado are addressed in this section. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as specified in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, can be used to fund components of the Animas-La Plata Project not covered in the Act.
